newsitem.title: USA: TWA sees higher Q1 oper loss than year ago.
newsitem.headline: TWA sees higher Q1 oper loss than year ago.

text.p: Trans World Airlines Inc on Monday said it expected its first-quarter operating loss to exceed its operating loss in the same period last year.
The carrier, which is expected to announce first-quarter results in April, posted an operating loss of $54.2 million in the first quarter of 1996 and a net loss of $37.1 million, or $0.89 a share.

In a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, TWA also said its consolidated cash and cash equivalents balance at the end of 1996 was $181.6 million, down from $304.3 million on December 31, 1995.

The seventh-largest U.S. carrier said its balances in the first quarter are typically lower than in other periods because of seasonal factors. TWA said such seasonal factors and the expected first-quarter loss will bring cash balances to a level significantly below the balance on December 31.

Last week, TWA said its independent audit would issue a qualification on the airline's ability to continue as a going concern. In the filing Monday, KPMG Peat Marwick LLP confirmed that TWA's recurring losses and its limited sources of fresh cash raised substantial doubts about its future as a going concern.

To be sure, TWA, which has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection twice since 1992, is taking steps to raise cash. Earlier this month, it sold a five percent stake to Saudi Arabian billionaire Prince al-Waleed bin Talal. On Monday, it closed a private placement of $50 million in secured notes.

The carrier is also looking for new projects to expand its cash-generating opportunities. It is installing automatic ticket machines in some markets and selling tickets on the Internet in the second quarter. The moves would reduce the carrier's ticket-distribution costs, TWA said in the filing.
The company also signed an agreement with a group of St. Louis businesses, which will buy $26 million of tickets for business travel on TWA flights.
In addition, TWA is considering entering a marketing and code-sharing alliance with foreign carriers, though further details were not available.

A TWA spokesman confirmed that management did not believe the resolution of claims related to the crash of TWA Flight 800 last July would have a material adverse effect on the carrier's financial condition or operational results.
The company said management had no reason to believe its insurance coverage would not be sufficient to cover whatever claims arose from the incident.
TWA shares closed up 2/16 at 6-15/16 on Monday.
